Award.AwardTitle: 16th Latin American Symposium on Mathematical Logic, July 28 - August 1, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration: This grant provides support for five US-based researchers and partial support for ten students/postdocs to participate in the 16th Latin American Mathematical Logic Symposium (SLALM) to be held on the Campus of Universidad de Buenos Aires, Argentina, July 28-August 1, 2014. The SLALM is the largest inter-American meeting in mathematical logic. It was established in 1970 to strengthen working relations between logicians in the United States and Latin America. Thanks in no small part to the success of these relations, today, mathematical logic thrives in Latin America. While the amount of research activity and the number of specialized conferences of international prestige that are held in the region continues to grow, the SLALM remains the largest inter-American logic conference. Since inception, the SLALM's have been organized in the form of a working conference preceded by a series of training tutorials aimed at students. The tutorials, the plenary talks, and the special sessions aim to represent major areas of mathematical logic. The SLALM has a strong tradition of being a student-focused event. The tutorials that precede the conference are attended by students from Latin America, the United States, and Canada. For the US students, the SLALM is a unique opportunity to attend lectures and tutorials given by some of the world's top logicians. The meeting is sponsored by the Association for Symbolic Logic. Abstracts of the talks have been published in the Bulletin of Symbolic, one of the three official journals of the Association.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Six participants from the United States - three invited speakers and three graduate students - were able to attend the 16th Latin American Logic Symposium (SLALM); the three students also attended the preconference tutorials.

The SLALM offered the following:

(a) Plenary talks by: Veronica Becher (University of Buenos Aires, Argentina), Lev Beklemishev (Steklov Mathematical Institute, Moscow, Russia), Oswaldo Chateubriand (Pontificia Universidade Catolica de Rio de Janeiro, Brasil), Peter Jipsen (Chapman University, USA), Stevo Todorvvic (University of Toronto, Canada), andBoris Zilber (University of Oxford, England),

(b) Tutorials given by: Menachem Magidor (Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel), Antonio Montalban (University of California, Berkeley, USA), and Isaac Golbring.

(c) Special sessions in the major areas of logic (Set Theory, Model Theory, Computability Theory and Nonclassical Logics).

The US beneficiaries were: Alfred Dolich, Peter Jipsen, and Isaac Goldbring (speakers) and Santiago Camach, Gabriel Conant, Gregory Cousins (students).

2.  Some of the participants of the 16th SLALM traveled San Antinio, Texas in 2015 for a follow-up conference held at The University of Texas at San Antonio . The research presented at this conference appeared in Agust 2017 the volume "Beyond First Order Model Theory", edited by the IP and published by CRC Press/ Taylor&Francis. 

3.  The PI was the main organizer of the workshop "Topological Methods in Model Theory" held in June 2016 at the Banff International Research Station (BIRS). This was an Inter American event.

4. In June 2017, Eduardo Duenez (UT San Antonio) attended the 17th Latin American Logic Symposium (SLALM) in Puebla, Mexico in part sponsored by this grant. Duenez attende the pre-conference minicourses and spoke at a special session.

5. In July 2017, the PI organized a special session at the 2017 Mathematical Congress of the Americas. Talks were given by: Nate Ackermann (Harvard), Xavier Caicedo (Universidad de los Andes), Eduardo Duenez (UT San Antonio), Christopher Eagle (Uiversity of Victoria) Bradd Hart (McMaster University), Isaac Goldbring (UC Irvine), Jose Iovino (UT San Atonio), Michael Makkai (McGill University), Henry Towsner (University of Pennsylvania), and Alessandro Vignati (York University).
